------=_NextPart_000_017E_01CA2E35.92DDBC30
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Colin,

Thankyou for the clarification about the genome compatability metri=
cs. I am currently working on a version of NEAT that will integrate with th=
e Neuroph Neural Network library in Java. I am trying to create a pluggable=
 version of NEAT as well so I can experiment with different compatability m=
etrics, and your explanation of how they currently work has helped greatly.=


I must admit I have implemented the first version you described and it se=
ems to work quite well, when I changed it to the second version I get some =
strange behaviour:

For a simple XOR experiment with 150 chromosomes for 50=
0 generations the speciation seems to create a lot more species than the S1=
 version. After (roughly) 145 generations there are 150 species for the sec=
ond version, versus the first version managing to get through the 500 gener=
ations creating 140 species. 

This is of course a new implementation of NE=
AT, so there could always be bugs in my code - however the different rate a=
t which the species are created is definately interesting. 

Have you seen =
any similar behaviour?

How would this specie saturation affect the perform=
ance of NEAT? If we have a fixed population size, and after 140 generations=
 every population member is in a specie all on it's own what affect will th=
is have on the results of the remaining 360 generations? If we use an eliti=
st strategy (which I keep the best organism in each specie, and throw the r=
est away) then we won't be able to get any further that the results from th=
e 140th generation?

I am currently working with a similarity metric for th=
e speciation based on behaviour. Instead of using the "behaviour" instead o=
f the fitness score like the novelty search, or using a MOEA of the fitness=
 and novelty I thought it would be interesting to try and speciate based on=
 the behaviour and see how well that compares with novelty search and the M=
OEA approach of fitness and novelty. I will provide some updates as I get f=
urther into my work.

This is my first post to the group - I did go back an=
d read your other posts about the compatability metric from the archive, an=
d a quick search didn't show up anyone else seeing this behaviour. However =
I do apologise if I have reposted something someone has already said.

Chee=
rs,

Aidan



  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: alienseedpod 
  To: n=
eat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Saturday, September 05, 2009 7:56 AM
  Subject=
: [neat] Compatibility Metric in Original NEAT


    Hi all,

  Earlier in =
the year I kicked off a discussion about genome compatibility metrics (AKA =
distance or similarity metrics). SharpNeat 2 (SN2) is nearing release and a=
llows metrics to be plugged and thus compared, there's a bit more to it tha=
n that and I'm currently writing some documentation to explain how this wil=
l work along with some issues to keep in mind, pros and cons, etc.

  Anywa=
y in writing up this stuff I ended up documenting how the original metric w=
orks, as described in the original NEAT paper in 2002. Now I've got a suspi=
cion that this came up long ago but in that paper the distance is given as:=


  d =3D c1*E/N + c2*D/N + c3*W

  (E,D are the # of excess and disjoint g=
enes. W is the total weight diff).

  N is the number of genes in the longe=
st genome. So the contribution of excess/disjoint genes to d is normalized.=
 In Ken's original code this equation is commented out and replaced with th=
e equivalent of:

  d =3D c1*E + c2*D + c3*W

  This makes more sense to me=
, it puts far more emphasis on the difference in topology than the first ve=
rsion and is sort of related to edit distance and manhattan distance. 

  F=
or the record SN1 also uses the latter equation and the other implementatio=
n I checked just now was ANJI2 which uses the former. Not sure what the imp=
lications of this are but I suspect it would have a significant effect on s=
peciation with secondary effects from there. Others may wish to review the =
metric in their implementations.

  Colin.
